Stasis Points and Approximating Two-Cycles
Stewart D. Johnson
Department of Mathematics and Statistics

Abstract
Generically, every fixed point for the differential inclusion x′ ∈ Convex Hull{f1 (x), f2 (x)}
can be approximated by an arbitrarily small two-cycle for the inclusion
x′ ∈ {f1 (x), f2 (x)}, where f1 , f2 are a C 1 flows on Rn .

Two-Flows, Stasis Points and Two-Cycles

Consider a controlled system that switches freely between two autonomous flows
x′ = f1 (x) and x′ = f2 (x) where x ∈ Rn and fi : Rn → Rn is C 1 . This is the
differential inclusion
x′ ∈ {f1 (x), f2 (x)}.
Trajectories are piecewise C 1 functions x(t) satisfying this inclusion.
A stasis point is a point x at where the flows are anti-parallel:
f1 (x) * f2 (x) = −|f1 (x)| * |f2 (x)|.
The set of stasis points is the set of possible fixed points for the relaxed differential inclusion
x′ ∈ Convex Hull({f1 (x), f2 (x)}).
A two-cycle x(t) is a periodic trajectory x(t) = x(δ + t) with 0 < κ < δ and

3

Two-Cycle Approximation to Stasis

It is known that relaxed solutions to differential inclusions can be arbitrarily
approximated by non-relaxed solutions [1, 2]. Here it is shown that in the case
of autonomous two-flows and relaxed fixed points, the approximating trajectory
can be taken as a two-cycle. For flows f1 , f2 , the idea is to take Rn modulo the
trajectories of f1 , and consider the remaining (non-autonomous) action of f2 on
Rn−1 . Loops in this resulting action will pull back to two-cycles in the original
system.

4

Three Questions

For R2 , every two cycle contains a stasis point [3]. Is a similar statement true
for Rn ?
Given a pair of flows f1 , f2 , the stasis points generically form one dimensional
curves. For n = 2, an approximating two cycle will cut across this curve twice,
and so the set of approximating two-cycles is parameterized by pairs of nearby
points on the stasis curve [3]. Is there a similar organization of two-cycles in
Rn ?
Finally, a natural question is to extend this to N -flows. That is, for a differential inclusion x′ ∈ {f1 (x), f2 (x), f3 (x)}, can a relaxed fixed point always be
approximated by a three-cycle?

References
[1] A. F. Filippov, Differential equations with discontinuous righthand sides,
Kluwer Academic, Dordrecht, The Netherlands, 1988.
[2] B. Ingalls, E.D. Sontag, Y. Wang, An infinite time relaxation theorem for
differential inclusions, Proc. of AMS, Vol 131, 2, Pages 487-499, 2002.
[3] S.D. Johnson, Stasis and two-cycles, SIAM J of Op Control, to appear.
